description: TO PASS THE RESOLUTION (J STAT, 369, 2-5-29), IN PURSUANCE OF A S.J.RES. PASSED IN 1819, REGULATING THE SUBJECT OF PRINTING FOR THE TWO HOUSES, AN ELECTION HAVING BEEN HAD BY THE SENATE DURING THE LAST SESSION FOR A PRINTER TO THE SENATE AND DUFF GREEN HVING RECEIVED THE MAJORITY VOTES, RESOLVED, THAT HE IS DULY ELECTED AS SUCH.

TO AGREE TO A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE CONVENTION BETWEEN THE U.S. AND THE FREE HANSEATIC REPUBLICS OF LUBECKS, BREMEN, AND HAMBURG, CONCLUDED AT WASHINGTON, DEC. 20, 1827.

TO AGREE TO A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY BETWEEN THE U.S. AND HIS MAJESTY THE KING OF SWEDEN AND NORWAY, CONCLUDED AT STOCKHOLM JULY 4, 1827, TOGETHER WITH THE SEPARATE ARTICLE THERETO.

TO AGREE TO A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE COMMERCIAL CONVENTION BETWEEN THE U.S. AND THE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND CONCLUDED AT LONDON, AUT. 6, 1827.

TO AMEND THE SENATE BILL ABOLISHING IMPRISONMENT FOR DEBT, BY ELIMINATING THE NINTH SECTION, PROVIDING THAT IN ALL CASES WHERE A PERSON IS SUBJECT TO IMPRISONMENT BY THIS ACT HE SHALL BE DEPRIVED OF THE BENEFIT OF PRISON BONDS, AND KEPT IN CUSTODY UNTIL ISCHARGED.

TO AGREE TO A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE CONVENTION RELATIVE TO THE NORTHEASTERN BOUNDARY BETWEEN THE U.S. AND THE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITIAN AND IRELAND, CONCLUDED AT LONDON, ON SEPT. 29, 1827.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF MOSES MYERS AS COLLECTOR OF THE CUSTOMS FOR THE DISTRICT OF NORFOLK AND PORTSMOUTH, VA.

TO AMEND THE IMPRISONMENT BILL BY PROPOSING TO HAVE THE DEFENDANT GIVE A SWORN STATEMENT OF HIS LIABILITIES AND ASSETS, AND THAT ALL CHATTELS OWNED BY HIM MAY BE DISPOSED OF AND APPLIED TO PAYMENT OF HIS DEBT AND JUDGEMENT ENTERED AGAINST HIM FOR THE REMINDER.
ON ORDERING ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE IMPRISON- MENT BILL.
TO PASS THE INPRISONMENT BILL.
TO PASS THE SENATE BILL (4 STAT. 304, 5-24-28), INCREASING THE PAY OF NAVY LIEUTENANTS, HAVING HAD TEN YEARS OR MORE SERVICE AS SUCH.

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT OF THE SENATE BILL, (4 STAT. 351, 3-2- 29), COMPLETING THE CUMBERLAND ROAD FROM BRIDGEPORT TO ZANESVILLE, OHIO, AND PROVIDING FOR THE SURVEY OF THE SAME FROM ZANSVILLE TO THE SEAT OF THE GOVERNMENT OF MO.

TO AGREE TO A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE CONVENTION RELATING TO THE NORTH WESTERN BOUNDARY BETWEEN THE U.S. AND THE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND, CONCLUDED AT LONDON AUG. 6, 1827.

TO RECOMMIT WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO THE COMMITTEE ON NAVAL AFFAIRS, TOGETHER WITH THE PAPER PURPORTING TO AN EXTRACT FROM THE JOURNAL OF F.C. DE KRAFFT, THE SENATE BILL IN SETTLEMENT OF THE CLAIM OF SUSAN DECATUR, FOUNDED ON THE RECAPTURE OF THE FRIGATE PHIADELPHIA IN THE HARBOR OF TRIPOLI IN 1804, WHICH HAD BEEN HELD FOR A CONSIDERABLE TIME BY THE ROYALISTS; INSTRUCTIONS BEING: TO EXAMINE THE CLAIMS OF THE OFFICERS AND CREW OF THE BRIG SYVEN, TO SHARE THE SUM GRANTED BY THE FIRST BILL.

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT OF THE SENATE BILL REGARDING THE SETTLEMENT OF THE CLAIM OF ABRAHAM OGDEN AND OTHERS FOR DAMAGES CAUSED BY DELAY AT LAGUIRA OF THE VESSEL PURPORTED TO HAVE BEEN CHARTERED SOLELY BY THE U.S., AGREEING TO PAY TO SAID OGDEN, $1000.

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT OF THE SENATE BILL IN SETTLEMENT OF THE CLAIM OF SUSAN DECATUR, FOUNDED IN THE RECAPTURE OF THE FRIGATE PHILADELPHIA, IN THE HARBOR OF TRIPOLI IN 1804, WHICH HAD BEEN HELD FOR A CONSIDERABLE TIME BY THE ROYALISTS.

TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO THE REPORT OF THE SELECT COMMITTEE OF FIVE APPOINTED TO REVISE AND ARRANGE THE RULES OF THE SENATE, AND TO REPORT SAME.  THE AMENDMENT TO THE REPORT PROVIDES TO ELIMINATE THAT THE QUESTION OF ORDER SHALL BE DECIDED BY THE PRESIDET OF THE SENATE WITHOUT DEBATE, BUT, IF HE IS IN DOUBT, HE MAY CALL FOR THE SENSE OF THE SENATE, AND PROVIDES IN LIEU THEREOF, THAT ON A QUESTION OR ORDER BY THE PRESIDENT OR SENATOR THE SAME SHALL BE DECIDED BY THE PRESIDENT WITHOUT DEBATE, SUBJECT TO AN...

TO AMEND THE PROCESSES IN THE COURTS BILL BY PROVIDING AS A FIRST NEW SECTION, THAT THE FORMS OF WRITS OF EXECUTION, AND OTHER PROCESS, EXCEPT THEIR STYLE FORMS AND MODES OF PROCEEDING IN SUITS IN THE COURTS OF THE U.S. HELD IN ANY OF THE STATES COMPOSIN THE UNION, IN THOSE OF COMMON LAW, SHALL BE SAME IN EACH OF SAID STATES, AS USED IN SUPREME COURTS OF SAME; IN PROCEEDINGS IN EQUITY, ACCORDING TO THE PRINCIPLES AND RULES OF COURT OF EQUITY IN SAID STATES, AND IN THOSE OF ADMIRALTY AND MARITIME JURISDIC...

TO AMEND THE PROCESSES IN THE COURTS BILL BY PROVIDING, AS A SECOND NEW SECTION, THAT IT BE FURTHER ENACTED, BY THE FORESAID AUTHORITY, THAT SO MUCH OF ANY ACT OF CONGRESS AS AUTHORIZES THE COURT OF THE U.S., OR THE SUPREME COURT, AT THEIR DISCRETION, TOAMEND ANY OF THE RULES, FORMS, MODES AND USAGES FORESAID, OR THE FORMS OF WRITS OF EXECUTION, AND OTHER PROCESS, EXCEPT THEIR STYLE SHALL BE, AND IS HEREBY REPEALED.

TO AMEND THE REPORT OF A SELECT COMMITTEE OF FIVE, APPOINTED TO REVISE AND ARRANGE THE RULES OF THE SENATE AND TO REPORT SAME WITH PROPER AMENDMENTS, BY PREVENTING THE PRESIDENT FROM RAISING A POINT OF ORDER, THEREBY GIVING SUCH PRIVILEGE TO A SENATOR ONY.
TO AMEND THE REPORT OF THE SELECT COMMITTEE, BY PROVIDING THAT THE PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE SHALL HAVE THE RIGHT TO DECIDE THE QUESTION ON A POINT OF ORDER.
TO AMEND THE REPORT OF A SELECT COMMITTEE BY PROVIDING, THAT THE DECISION OF THE PRESIDENT ON A QUESTION OF ORDER SHALL BE SUBJECT TO AN APPEAL TO THE SENATE.
TO PASS THE SENATE BILL RESTORING SIMON WEBSTER, A SOLDIER OF THE REVOLUTION, TO THE LIST OF REVOLUTIONARY PENSIONERS.

TO AGREE TO A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE SENATE ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE RATIFICATION OF THE TREATY MADE AT THE COUNCIL HOUSE, AT BUFFALO CREEK AUG. 31, 1826, WITH THE SENACA TRIBE OF INDIANS AS SOON AS THE PRESIDENT SHALL BE SATISFIED THAT THE PURCHSE MONEY HAS BEEN PAID, AGREEABLY TO THE PROVISIONS OF THE TREATY.

TO AMEND, IN NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE, THE RESOLUTION THAT THE OFFICE OF MAJOR GENERAL OF THE U.S. ARMY IS UNNCESSARY IN TIME OF PEACE, AND OUGHT NOW BE ABOLISHED, AND THAT THE COMMITTEE ON MILITARY AFFAIRS BE INSTRUCTED TO BRING IN A BILL FOR THE ABOLISHMNT OF SAME, BY PROPOSING THAT THE COMMITTEE ON MILITARY AFFAIRS BE INSTRUCTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE EXPEDIENCY OF CONTINUING OR ABOLISHING THE OFFICE OF MAJOR GENERAL OF THE UNITED STATES ARMY.
